Award.AwardTitle: Template-Based Undergraduate Education in Wireless Application Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Engineering - Electrical (55)
This project is developing learning modules in the area of software application development for wireless mobile devices. The modules are being developed such that they can be incorporated into conventional communication systems and technology courses or offered as components of independent-study or senior design courses. The learning modules are also incorporating active and collaborative learning strategies. The specific goals of the project are (1) to develop a wireless application library for cellular phones where each application can serve as a template for students to develop their own projects, (2) to develop associated learning modules to teach students the process of developing, compiling, and embedding applications in cellular phones, and (3) to develop cellular phone applications that allow students to explore a variety of fundamental communications and signal processing principles, including convolution and the fast Fourier transform. The project is also developing a cellular phone application that enables students to use cellular phones, rather than single purpose clickers, as part of a classroom response system. The wireless application library and associated learning modules are being made available for free download from the project's website. The project includes formative and summative evaluation plans for all aspects of the project coordinated by an independent evaluator.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cell phones are one of most ubiquitous portable technology devices available. They significantly influenced daily life by providing continuous access to various communication media. New services are added almost every day and cellular technology has become a bright example of co-evolution of human society and information technology. Development of wireless technologies and applications is based on advanced technological concepts which are not typically covered by the conventional undergraduate courses. For the US economy to remain competitive in wireless communications, undergraduate engineering education should help the workforce with appropriate training strategies and course materials.

The objective of this proposal was to implement and demonstrate a novel concept of template-based undergraduate education in wireless application development.  The training material is composed of educational modules which can be incorporated either in conventional communication or computing technology courses, or offered as components of independent-study courses. The approach helps to overcome course-load constraints peculiar to current engineering undergraduate programs. The following materials and strategies are addressed.

An educational wireless application library for cell-phones is developed where each application can serve as a template for students to develop their own projects; the associated learning materials help students to understand the process of developing, compiling and embedding applications in phones, use reach capabilities of modern cell phones such as text, voice, audio, imaging in the applications. The novelty of the approach is based on the fact that learning is a layered process, and one can convey complex concepts and skills at various abstraction levels that are understandable to undergraduate and even K12 students. Ready-made 'templates' can be studied and manilulated to understand the mobile application development chain without lengthy preliminary knowledge accumulation. Once exposed to the whole development chain, students will be motivated to learn more details.

To assess the efficiency of the approach, the project offered short training courses based on the proposed 'template'-based mobile application development. Course materials and video-training modules were also developed to support the program. The courses were initially offered as one-hour modules at two high schools in San Antonio, TX (Thomas C. Clarks, Sandra Day O'Connor), to about 50 participants. Then more extensive training module was included in undergraduate 'Wireless Communications' class at the University of Texas in San Antonio, in 2012. About 40 students were able to implement mobile applications without any prior exposure to mobile application development. The undergraduate module was ten hours long. Finally, similar short courses are offered to middle school students (~20 participants) and K12 teachers (13 participants).

Attitude survey data were collected for assessments. The data analysis demonstrated that the proposed method significantly impacts students’ self-confidence and mitigates their fears of mobile application development complexity.

In addition to the main goal described above, the project advanced remote technology to provide access to experimentation modules for hands-on training and project development purposes. Both software and hardware platforms evolve very quickly and it is important for education to have an early and simplified access to advanced technology environments. The project developed an approach that facilitates students’ access to remote experimentation, and will also assist online training on mobile platforms and applications.
